Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
8/8/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
FOM 722 – O8D Treatment plans Agreement and Signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker
Must obtain signatures from the following
Individuals, as applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when sibling in care
are place apart.
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and
unrelated court – ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youths, and caregivers
must check yes or no for the following when signing
the treatment plan:
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to
review, and I will have the opportunity to
express my disagreement with the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan when
the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must
2

identify and document actions needed to secure the
parent’s and/or youth’s participation in service
planning and compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures
pages into the electronic case record within 30 days
of the report date.

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. All CAPS
were address and there was no repeat violation.
The renewal inspection was completed on 6/14/2022, and the CAP was accepted
on 6/28/2022. The rules in violation were 400. 12418 (2,b), FOM 722.08C and
ADM 980. There was no repeat violations.
The special investigation report #2022C0420013, was generated on 2/18/2022,
and the agency was in violation with rule 400.12324 reevaluation. The presented
an acceptable CAP and there was no repeat violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator was interviewed onsite, and she reported barriers and
systemic factors that have impacted rules, ISEP, policy and contract violations
since the last audit. She reported there has been a series of trainings to promote
uniformity in the methods to respond to different areas to strengthen the agency.
There has also been an increase in training support for new workers when they
are completing 'field training' during their first 9 weeks. These training span from
various topics from navigating MiSACWIS, court reports, navigating resources and
Ennis Policies.
Financial Overview
The agency annual budget and audit reports was reviewed, it showed a surplus for
their fiscal year.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed reported they feel good working for the agency. There was a
common theme whereby the staff reported good teamwork and
supervisor/administrative support within the agency. Staff reported they do not
feel pressured or micromanaged. Staff reported they love their environment and
would only change the amount of paperwork they have to complete so they can
spend more time with families and youth they serve.
There were no youth interviews by this Consultant.
Description of Agency Walk Through

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts/concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that Ennis Center for Children continue on their regular license.
